subject: Critical Thinking
title: David Hume: The Great Skeptic of Cause and Effect
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: David Hume: The Great Skeptic of Cause and Effect.

hook.text: The sun has risen every day of recorded history. Will it rise tomorrow?

buildup.text: David Hume's 'problem of induction': past patterns don't logically guarantee future ones.

discovery.text: Hume showed that causation itself is unobservable. You see billiard ball A hit B, then B moves.

twist.text: This doesn't mean science is wrong â€“ it means science rests on assumptions that can't themselves be scientifically.

climax.text: Hume's skepticism was constructive: it forces us to be humble about certainty & precise about what evidence can &.

punchline.text: Correlation isn't causation. Hume proved it 300 years ago.

quiz.question: What is Hume's 'problem of induction'?
options: Past patterns don't logically guarantee future ones; we assume but can't prove continuity
